I will make a statement that probably better belongs on another list, but I=
'll make it here and welcome either private responses or an invitation to a=
 more appropriate place to discuss this.

I do not react well to calling J2=
EE implementation idioms "patterns". They are hacks designed to increase pe=
rformance and work around the obvious limitations and faulty intentions of =
J2EE.

Session facade is not a "pattern" in the sense of "improves design".=
 It is a hack that gets around the fact that J2EE tries to hide RMI from th=
e programmer. If we didn't have to worry about remote objects, then how wou=
ld we design it? I don't think we'd arrive at these implementation idioms/h=
acks if it weren't for working around either remote objects or a persistenc=
e mechanism that tries to call "save" for every method call.

Comments?

So=
 said steven.hale@... on 4/4/2003 --------------------

ke here - and would even go one step further. Using junit
and tdd with sess=
ion ejbs encourages the 'ejb front' pattern (is this the
right name?) which=
 is a good thing.

Cactus has both pros and cons.

Steven Hale
